nodes.text: State-level economic policy uncertainty can be measured and used to study how state and national sources of policy uncertainty affect state economic outcomes
We construct three monthly state-level EPU indexes for each U.S. state: EPU-S (state/local sources), EPU-N (national/international sources), and EPU-C (composite)

We compile digital archives of about 3,500 local newspapers (median 49 papers per state-month) and flag articles containing economy, uncertainty, and policy term sets tailored to national or state contexts
Raw state-level EPU indexes are the fraction of articles with Economy, Uncertainty, and policy terms divided by total articles in same papers, normalized to a base period and scaled by 100
We make all state EPU series available and use them to study drivers (elections, national events, pandemic) and economic effects using panel and state VARs and spatial extensions

Descriptive evidence: before COVID, articles mentioning only national policy accounted for 50% of EPU-C on average, only state/local 30%, both 20%; after March 2020 national-only share fell and state/local-only share rose substantially

Elections raise state-level policy uncertainty: presidential elections raise EPU-N, gubernatorial elections raise EPU-S, and close elections (margin <4%) produce much larger increases (close pres: +60% EPU-N; close governor: +35% EPU-S)
Selected national and international events (9-11, debt-ceiling crisis, Brexit, Trump 2016, government shutdowns) produced large, heterogeneous one-month spikes in EPU-N across most states

The COVID-19 pandemic produced very large increases in EPU: average EPU-N rose to 2.7 times pre-COVID peak and average EPU-S rose to more than four times prior peak, with the locus shifting toward state/local sources

Illustrative state episodes: California electricity crisis (2000-01) and 2003 recall raised EPU-S markedly; Kansas tax cuts (2012) raised EPU-S; Hurricane Katrina raised both EPU-S and EPU-N; Michigan exposed to national shocks during the Great Recession

There is substantial heterogeneity across states and over time in the relative importance of state vs national EPU; correlations across states are moderate and spatial proximity does not strongly predict EPU co-movement

Panel VAR results (44-state panel, 2001-2019): upward own-state EPU-C shocks foreshadow higher unemployment and lower employment with hump-shaped responses peaking about one year later (peak unemployment response ~0.10 percentage points for a unit sd shock)

Extensions and robustness: spillovers from neighboring-state EPU-C shocks materially raise own-state unemployment; VARs show weaker but signiï¬cant negative responses for housing permits and prices and mixed evidence for business formation; larger states show larger responses

Pandemic-era cross-state regression evidence: state lockdown stringency (index of shelter-in-place, business, restaurant, school closure orders) strongly predicts larger increases in state EPU from 2019 to pandemic quarters, whereas COVID deaths per capita do not

Pandemic-era outcomes: states with stricter lockdowns experienced larger increases in unemployment relative to 2019, and larger EPU increases are associated with larger unemployment increases conditional on lockdowns and deaths, though causal interpretation is cautious

Overall conclusion: state-level newspaper-based EPU indexes reveal that state and local policy matter substantially for measured policy uncertainty, election and pandemic policies drive large state heterogeneity, EPU shocks foreshadow weaker state economic performance and spill across borders, and the pandemic shifted uncertainty toward subnational sources
